questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of severe acne on her face, chest, and back for the past 2 years. She has no itching or scaling. She has been treated in the past with oral azithromycin and a topical combination of benzoyl peroxide and adapalene without clinical improvement. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild facial scarring and numerous open comedones and sebaceous skin lesions on her face, chest, and back. Before initiating treatment, which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Screen for depression with a questionnaire

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Before initiating oral retinoid therapy in women of childbearing age, an approved form of primary contraception (e.g., combined oral contraceptive pill) and a secondary barrier method must be initiated. Progestin-only oral contraceptives are not as effective as combined oral contraceptive pills and are not recommended for contraception in patients taking oral retinoids. Moreover, a different step is necessary before combined oral contraceptive pills are initiated.

Combined oral contraceptive pills have an antiandrogenic effect and can be used as an adjunct to treat severe inflammatory acne but progestin-only contraception can worsen acne.

B) INCORRECT:

Depression and suicidal ideation have been reported in patients taking retinoids, but current research does not support a causative link between this group of drugs and depression. A formal questionnaire-based screening test for depression is not routinely performed before initiating therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetracyclines such as doxycycline should be avoided in patients receiving systemic treatment with retinoids because both drugs increase the risk of pseudotumor cerebri. If adjunctive antibiotic therapy is indicated (e.g., because of inflammatory acne), amoxicillin or cephalexin are acceptable agents.

D) CORRECT:

Two separate serum or urine pregnancy tests should be performed in all female patients prior to systemic therapy with retinoids because this group of drugs is extremely teratogenic. If the initial pregnancy tests are negative, an approved form of primary contraception (e.g., IUD, combined oral contraceptive pill) and a secondary barrier method (e.g., condoms, cervical cap plus spermicide, diaphragm plus spermicide) must be used for a month before initiating oral retinoid therapy and continued up until one month after treatment is completed. Pregnancy tests should be repeated monthly while systemic retinoid therapy is ongoing and one month after ceasing therapy.

This patient should also undergo liver function and lipid profile tests (both before and during therapy) since the use of retinoids is associated with impaired liver function and hyperlipidemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic retinoid therapy can occasionally result in rhabdomyolysis and increased creatinine kinase (CK) levels. CK levels should be measured if the patient develops myalgia during treatment, but routine pretherapeutic measurement is not necessary.

F) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum androgens (e.g., DHEA-S, total and free testosterone, androstenedione) in a female patient with acne vulgaris is only indicated if features of polycystic ovarian syndrome (e.g., ultrasonographic evidence of polycystic ovaries, menstrual irregularities), Cushing syndrome (e.g., truncal obesity), or hyperandrogenism (e.g., precocious puberty, hirsutism, clitoromegaly) are present.
questions.hint: This patient with severe acne vulgaris has failed to respond to initial therapy. As a next step, treatment with an oral retinoid (e.g., isotretinoin) should be initiated.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of acne on her face and chest. She has no itching or scaling. She is concerned about the possibility of facial scarring and has never sought treatment. She has no history of serious illness. She takes no medications. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (130 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several open comedones on the face and chest. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics can be used for the treatment of moderate to severe acne vulgaris, but they should be used in combination with another agent to prevent bacterial resistance and for an additional comedolytic or keratin-reducing effect. This patient has mild noninflammatory acne vulgaris, which means that oral antibiotics would not be the first-line treatment.

B) CORRECT:

Monotherapy with topical benzoyl peroxide is a first-line treatment option for mild noninflammatory acne vulgaris. Benzoyl peroxide has a comedolytic as well as a bactericidal effect, which can reduce Cutibacterium acnes colonization. Benzoyl peroxide also prevents bacterial resistance and should be added to topical or systemic antibiotic regimens. Other first-line treatment options for mild acne vulgaris include topical retinoid monotherapy, benzoyl peroxide + topical antibiotics, benzoyl peroxide + topical retinoid, and benzoyl peroxide + topical antibiotic + topical retinoid. The choice of medication depends on the severity of acne vulgaris, provider preference, and prior treatment.
Image Description:

The skin of the patient shows multiple papules and pustules on an erythematous base. In addition, several open comedones with the characteristic darkening (blackheads) are visible.

These findings are characteristic of acne vulgaris.

C) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives can be prescribed as an adjunct therapy for female patients who do not respond to first-line therapy of acne vulgaris. Since this patient has not yet trialed any first-line treatments, combined oral contraceptives are not indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with topical antibiotics is not recommended for acne vulgaris treatment because of the potential development of antibiotic resistance. Instead, topical or systemic antibiotics should be used in conjunction with another specific agent in which there has been no reported resistance.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral isotretinoin is reserved for the treatment of severe acne vulgaris (e.g., nodular acne) and moderate inflammatory acne that causes scarring because of its severe side effect profile (e.g., hepatic toxicity, birth defects). This patient has mild acne vulgaris and has not yet received a first-line treatment. Therefore, oral isotretinoin would not be appropriate at this time.
questions.hint: Open comedones (also known as blackheads) on the face and chest are characteristic of mild noninflammatory acne vulgaris.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 18-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of severe acne vulgaris over her face, upper back, and arms. Treatment with oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy with benzoyl peroxide and retinoid has not completely resolved her symptoms. Examination shows oily skin with numerous comedones, pustules, and scarring over the face and upper back. Long-term therapy is started with combined oral contraceptives. This patient's new medication significantly reduces the risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-term COC use (â‰¥ 5 years) is associated with an increased risk of developing cervical cancer. The mechanism by which they do this is unclear, but it is hypothesized that these medications increase the susceptibility of cervical cells to human papillomavirus infection (the main cause of cervical cancer) and/or decrease the ability of cervical cells to clear this infection.

B) CORRECT:

For female patients with continued severe acne vulgaris despite first-line therapies (e.g., oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy), COCs can be added. Besides having positive effects on acne vulgaris, the progestin contained in COCs opposes estrogen-driven endometrial hyperplasia, which reduces the risk of developing type 1 endometrial cancer. This risk decreases with a longer duration of COC use, and protection persists for many years after drug cessation. COCs also reduce the risk of developing ovarian cancer, possibly through reduced cell proliferation within the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

C) INCORRECT:

COC therapy is associated with an increased risk of developing deep vein thrombosis since estrogen induces transcription of clotting factors (II, VII, VIII, X, XII) and fibrinogen to promote clot formation.

D) INCORRECT:

COC therapy increases the risk of developing hypertension, although this risk minimizes shortly after drug cessation. The mechanism of oral contraception-induced hypertension is unclear but may be related to increased serum angiotensinogen concentrations.

E) INCORRECT:

COC therapy does not reduce the risk of developing breast cancer. However, there is controversy as to whether these medications actually increase the risk of developing breast cancer and, therefore, should be used with caution in patients with high risk for breast cancer development (e.g., due to BRCA mutations).

F) INCORRECT:

COCs increase the risk of developing hepatic adenomas. Although the mechanism is not fully understood, it may be related to estrogen-induced vascular dilation.
questions.hint: Progestin, a component of combined oral contraceptives (COCs), opposes the effects of estrogen.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of severe acne that involves her face, chest, and back. It has not improved with her current therapy of oral cephalexin and a topical combination of benzoyl peroxide and adapalene. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms consistently. Facial scarring and numerous comedones are present, with sebaceous skin lesions on her face, chest, and back. Before initiating treatment, which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Measure serum DHEA-S and testosterone levels

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Since retinoids are extremely teratogenic, all patients who can become pregnant must undergo a serum pregnancy test that quantitatively measures hCG levels or a urine pregnancy test that measures these qualitatively prior to initiation of therapy. The pregnancy test should be repeated monthly up to one month after ceasing systemic retinoid therapy. Meanwhile, the patient should commit to a "double" contraception strategy, a combination of an oral as well as another contraceptive (e.g., barrier contraception, IUD). Contraception should start one month before isotretinoin therapy and be continued until one month after isotretinoin therapy is completed. Since the use of a retinoid is frequently associated with decreased liver function and hyperlipidemia, regular liver function and lipid profile tests (both before and during therapy) are recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Isotretinoin therapy can occasionally result in rhabdomyolysis and increased creatinine kinase (CK) levels. CK levels would be measured if the patient develops myalgia during therapy with isotretinoin, but routine pretherapeutic measurement of CK levels is not necessary (unlike in statin therapy).

C) INCORRECT:

Tetracyclines such as doxycycline should be avoided if patients are taking retinoids because both drugs increase the risk of pseudotumor cerebri, which could lead to an additive effect in combination. If adjunctive antibiotic therapy is indicated (e.g., because of inflammatory acne) while the patient is taking retinoids, amoxicillin or cephalexin are acceptable agents.

D) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, isotretinoin therapy causes optic neuritis and, subsequently, impaired color vision. However, routine pretherapeutic screening for impaired color vision is not necessary when initiating isotretinoin therapy.

Pretherapeutic screening for impaired color vision is necessary when initiating ethambutol therapy for tuberculosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A female patient who is taking isotretinoin should receive oral contraceptive therapy to prevent pregnancy. A combination of ethinyl estradiol with a progestin (e.g., norgestimate, norethidrone, drospirenone) may also be used as therapy for patients with severe inflammatory acne vulgaris or acne associated with hyperandrogenism. However, a different step is necessary before oral contraceptive therapy can be considered.

F) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum androgens (e.g., DHEA-S, total and free testosterone, androstenedione) in a female patient with acne is indicated only if clinical features of polycystic ovarian syndrome (e.g., ultrasonographic evidence of polycystic ovaries, menstrual irregularities), Cushing syndrome (e.g., truncal obesity), or features suggestive of hyperandrogenism (e.g, precocious puberty, hirsutism, clitoromegaly) are present. Routine measurement of serum androgen levels in a patient with acne vulgaris is not necessary.
questions.hint: Treatment with oral retinoids (e.g., isotretinoin) is indicated for forms of (severe) acne vulgaris that have not been responsive to treatment with a combination of oral antibiotics and topical agents. However, systemic retinoid therapy can have severe side effects.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the physician because of skin changes on his face, chest, and back over the past year. Treatment with over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide has been ineffective. Physical examination shows numerous open comedones, inflammatory papules, and pustules on his face, chest, and back. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patientâ€™s skin condition?

choices.text: Formation of superficial epidermal inclusion cyst

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dysfunction of apocrine glands is believed to contribute to hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), an inflammatory skin disorder affecting areas with abundant apocrine sweat glands including the axilla, groin, and perineum. Lesions in HS can form abscesses, fistulas, and draining sinuses with foul odor. This patient exhibits none of these clinical features.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperplasia of pilosebaceous glands occurs in rosacea with phymatous changes. Rosacea typically affects individuals 30â€“60 years old, and can cause disfiguring enlargement of the nose, known as rhinophyma. This patient has comedonal lesions, which are not expected in rosacea, and he does not have rhinophyma or other symptoms of rosacea.

C) INCORRECT:

Formation of superficial epidermal inclusion cysts is the underlying mechanism of milia. Milia is a benign skin disorder typically affecting neonates, marked by small white papules on the nose and cheeks that resolve spontaneously. The inflammatory, comedonal nature of this patient's skin lesions and distribution on the face, back, and chest are inconsistent with milia.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperkeratinization of hair follicles is the underlying mechanism of keratosis pilaris, which results in rough bumps distributed over the extensor surfaces of the arms and thighs. This patient has characteristic lesions on the face, back, and chest that suggest a different disorder and pathophysiology.

E) CORRECT:

Increased levels of androgen, as present during puberty, stimulate sebum production, which can lead to the obstruction of pilosebaceous units within the epidermis. This obstruction results in clogged pores, or comedones, which are characteristic of acne vulgaris. In response to excessive sebum secretion, Cutibacterium acnes can proliferate within the pilosebaceous unit and induce an inflammatory reaction with the formation of papules, nodules, pustules, and/or cysts.
Image Description:

Disseminated papules, pustules, and comedones on an erythematous base are visible on the seborrheic skin of the patient's forehead.

These findings are consistent with moderate acne vulgaris.

F) INCORRECT:

A type IV hypersensitivity reaction is the mechanism underlying allergic contact dermatitis, which occurs in susceptible individuals after repeat skin exposure to an allergen. Lesions in allergic contact dermatitis are intensely pruritic, erythematous, and papular, although they can also be vesicular in nature. The distribution and characterization of the lesions in this patient are not consistent with allergic contact dermatitis.
questions.hint: Open comedones and inflammatory papules and pustules in an adolescent patient are characteristic of acne vulgaris, an extremely common disorder of pilosebaceous follicles.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of a rash on her face. She says that the rash first appeared after she tried a new makeup product. The rash is not itchy or painful. She reports that it has negatively affected her confidence in public and her academic performance has suffered considerably as a result of stress. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive pill. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.2Â°C (99.0Â°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows the findings in the photograph. A similar rash is seen on her back. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Colonization of hair follicles by gram-negative rods
Superficial infection with a dermatophytic fungus
Mutation of a tumor supressor gene
Delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a topically applied substance

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disseminated infection with the spirochete Treponema pallidum causes secondary syphilis, which can also manifest with a nonpruritic papular rash that involves the back. However, the rash seen in patients with syphilis is more commonly maculopapular and generalized rather than papulopustular and confined to the face and back; in addition, the entire trunk, extremities, palms, and soles are usually affected, with the face typically being spared. Finally, this patient lacks additional features of secondary syphilis such as generalized lymphadenopathy, constitutional symptoms, condylomata lata, and patchy alopecia.
Image Description:

A nodular, partially pustular, copper-colored rash with some superficial scaling is visible over the back, arms, and shoulders. The palms and soles of the feet are typically also affected.

These findings are consistent with a rash seen in secondary syphilis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperreactivity of cutaneous blood vessels has been implicated in the pathogenesis of rosacea, which can also manifest with papules and pustules. However, skin manifestations in rosacea are more commonly localized to the central face rather than the forehead, and comedones are not present. Additional symptoms of rosacea include facial flushing and erythema, phymatous changes, and ocular involvement, none of which are seen in this patient. Finally, rosacea most commonly affects women over the age of 30 years.
Image Description:

Papules, pustules, and erythema can be seen on the forehead, nose, and cheeks. A coarse, erythematous, and enlarged bulbous nose (rhinophyma) is also visible.

C) INCORRECT:

Colonization of hair follicles by gram-negative rods, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, can lead to folliculitis, which manifests with papules and pustules. However, pseudomonal folliculitis typically occurs shortly after exposure to contaminated water (often found in hot tubs), which this patient has no history of. Moreover, the lesions of pseudomonas folliculitis are located at the base of the hair follicles with one or multiple hairs emerging from the lesion; the face is usually spared. Finally, comedones are not seen in folliculitis.
Image Description:

Multiple pustules with surrounding erythema can be seen emerging from the hair follicles.

D) CORRECT:

Acne vulgaris, which typically occurs during adolescence, is caused by inflammation of the pilosebaceous unit. Increased sebum production by sebaceous glands due to hormonal stimulation (i.e., increased androgen production in puberty), and accumulating keratin debris due to increased keratinocyte activity leads to blockage of the pilosebaceous duct, resulting in the formation of comedones. As a response to excessive sebum secretion, Cutibacterium acnes proliferates within the pilosebaceous unit and induces an inflammatory reaction with the formation of papules, nodules, pustules, and/or cysts. Factors thought to contribute to the development of acne vulgaris include genetic susceptibility and environmental factors (e.g., diet, stress). Initial treatment of mild acne vulgaris usually consists of topical agents (e.g., benzoyl peroxide, retinoids); however, in a patient with significant acne-related psychological distress, adding systemic therapy (e.g., tetracycline) may be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Superficial infection with a dermatophytic fungus causes tinea, which can manifest with papules and pustules. However, tinea more commonly causes round, erythematous, pruritic plaques with raised borders and a central clearing. Furthermore, tinea typically spares the face and, instead, affects other areas of the skin (e.g., torso, groin, or feet), hair, or nails.
Image Description:

A round, well-demarcated, erythematous plaque with peripheral scaling is visible on the right cheek (borders indicated by black arrows).

F) INCORRECT:

A mutation of a tumor suppressor gene is the underlying etiology of tuberous sclerosis, which can also manifest with erythematous papules on the face (adenoma sebaceous). However, these papules are more common around the nose and cheeks rather than the forehead and usually appear early in life (between 3â€“4 years of age). Additionally, comedones are not seen in patients with adenoma sebaceum. Finally, most patients with tuberous sclerosis present with neurological findings (e.g., epilepsy due to brain tumors, cognitive deficits, learning disabilities), which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Multiple papules, resembling acne, can be seen on this patient's face.

These findings are suggestive of adenoma sebaceum, a cutaneous condition in patients with tuberous sclerosis characterized by the presence of angiofibromas.

G) INCORRECT:

Delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a topically applied substance is the underlying mechanism of allergic contact dermatitis, which can also manifest with a papular rash at the site of exposure to a cosmetic product. However, this condition presents 12â€“48 hours after repeated contact with an allergen rather than after initial contact and usually resolves with avoidance of the antigen; this patient has a 1-year history of cutaneous lesions. Additionally, the rash in contact dermatitis is often intensely pruritic, erythematous, and, in severe cases, vesicular; contact dermatitis does not manifest with comedones.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.
questions.hint: The photograph shows papulopustular lesions and closed comedones.

questions.text: A 3-week-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She has been well, but her mother is concerned about a rash that appeared on her cheeks 6 days ago. She has not had any other symptoms. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery and is exclusively breastfed. There is no family history of serious illness. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 75th percentile for length and weight and at the 60th percentile for head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's rash is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding this newborn's rash?

choices.text: Breathable fabrics and avoidance of heat
Daily cleansing with water and soap

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Breathable fabrics and avoidance of heat are measures used to avoid and treat miliaria rubra. Although miliaria rubra also manifests with an erythematous, papulopustular rash, it more commonly develops in areas that are prone to sweating and occlusion (e.g., intertriginous skin folds of the neck, axilla, and groin). Breathable fabrics and avoidance of heat are unlikely to improve neonatal cephalic pustulosis.
Image Description:

Multiple, partially confluent papules on erythematous skin are visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical mupirocin is used to treat impetigo, which can manifest with erythematous papules and pustules. However, these lesions typically rupture and leave shallow erosions covered in honey-colored crust. Moreover, children between the ages of 2 and 4 are most commonly affected. Topical mupirocin is not used to treat neonatal cephalic pustulosis.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical tacrolimus is used to treat atopic dermatitis, often in conjunction with topical corticosteroids. Atopic dermatitis can manifest in infancy with an erythematous rash on the face but more commonly results in scaly, eczematous plaques without pustules. In addition, these lesions are often intensely pruritic and cause discomfort and irritability. Topical tacrolimus is not used to treat neonatal cephalic pustulosis.
Image Description:

Erythematous and scaly papules coalescing into plaques can be seen on the face of this infant.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral isotretinoin can be used to treat severe infantile acne. Although this condition usually manifests with erythematous papules and pustules, the presentation is usually much more severe than that of neonatal cephalic pustulosis and also includes comedones (and sometimes nodules). Moreover, infantile acne most commonly manifests around 3 months of age. Oral isotretinoin is not used to treat neonatal cephalic pustulosis.

E) CORRECT:

Neonatal cephalic pustulosis is a benign, self-limited condition that typically resolves within a few months and does not leave scars. Management includes daily cleansing with water and soap and avoidance of oils and lotions, which can occlude the skin and exacerbate this condition. More severe cases can be treated with topical antifungals (e.g., ketoconazole cream) and mild topical corticosteroids (e.g., hydrocortisone cream).
questions.hint: This patient has neonatal cephalic pustulosis, which most commonly manifests in the first few weeks of life on the face and/or scalp with an erythematous, papulopustular rash without comedones.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman with a 15-year history of acne expresses frustration with her current therapy (10% benzoyl peroxide wash and 0.025% tretinoin cream) because she continues to get inflammatory papules and pustules and occasional deep-seated cystic lesions on her face, chest, and back. She does not have extensive scarring and is not pregnant or planning pregnancy.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics (including clindamycin) are used to treat mild-to-moderate inflammatory acne. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

B) CORRECT:

Acne is very common in adolescents and is also prevalent in young adults. Acne severity can be classified clinically as mild, moderate, or severe â€” and more precisely as comedonal (clogged pores), inflammatory (papules and pustules), nodulocystic, or a combination of these. This patient has predominantly inflammatory acne that has failed to respond to appropriate topical therapy. There are several potential treatment options for her, including addition of an oral antibiotic, hormonal therapy such as oral contraceptive pills, and isotretinoin.

Of the answer choices listed, an oral antibiotic is best. Tetracyclines (doxycycline, minocycline, and sarecycline) are among the most commonly used oral antibiotics for acne and are considered to be the most effective antibiotics for this purpose.

Ideally, this patient will continue the benzoyl peroxide and retinoid (in addition to starting the oral antibiotic), to control coincident comedonal disease and in anticipation of tapering or discontinuing the oral therapy. If no improvement is noted after 3 months of oral therapy, the oral antibiotic may be changed, hormonal therapy may be instituted, and/or isotretinoin can be considered. Isotretinoin is indicated when patients have severe nodulocystic acne or scarring that has not responded to oral antibiotics. Since prolonged treatment with oral antibiotics is not recommended because of the potential for bacterial resistance, more providers are opting for hormonal therapies and/or isotretinoin upon failure of one systemic antibiotic.

Key learning point: Inflammatory acne that has not responded to appropriate topical therapy is best treated with an oral antibiotic, such as doxycycline.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical retinoids (including tretinoin and tazarotene) are used to treat comedonal acne, while topical antibiotics (including clindamycin) are used to treat mild-to-moderate inflammatory acne. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

D) INCORRECT:

Combination topical agents such as clindamycin-benzoyl peroxide are convenient for the patient and increase efficacy by increasing compliance, but they do not offer additional efficacy for severe inflammatory and cystic disease. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical retinoids (including tretinoin and tazarotene) are used to treat comedonal acne. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents with progressively worsening skin lesions on his face. He has been treating the lesions with antibacterial soap and witch hazel astringent with no improvement. He uses no other cosmetics or medications on his face. He is healthy and takes no systemic medications.
On physical examination, he generally appears well. He has extensive open and closed comedones on the face (figure). There is dyspigmentation (consistent with postinflammatory hyperpigmentation) but no obvious scarring on the face.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has moderate facial acne with a predominance of comedones. The extent of pigmentary changes at sites of prior acne lesions further supports the diagnosis of moderate acne. Topical retinoid preparations are the first-line therapy for comedonal acne. Topical retinoids (creams or gels) are also effective for treating mild-to-moderate inflammatory papulopustular acne vulgaris.

Recognizing the distinct morphologies in acne vulgaris guides selection of treatment. In a patient with predominantly comedonal acne, a topical retinoid, such as tretinoin 0.025% or adapalene 0.1% cream or gel, is an excellent first-line choice. Alternative (second-line) keratolytic agents include salicylic acid, glycolic acid, and azelaic acid. Topical azelaic acid may also help improve pigmentary changes. Cleansing with benzoyl peroxide may be helpful for patients with comedonal acne, because it is a mild keratolytic and has antibacterial properties that may help to prevent development of other types of acne such as pustules.

Topical or systemic antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin, doxycycline) should not be used as monotherapy and are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease. Adjunctive antibiotic therapy may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris, especially when it involves the back or chest, because consistently applying topical medications over these anatomic sites can be a challenge. Antibiotic therapy is not recommended for extended periods of time (more than 6 to 12 months) given the potential risk for developing antibiotic resistance. If acne does not respond to systemic antibiotic therapy after 3 to 6 months, treatment with isotretinoin is often considered. Isotretinoin is also frequently considered earlier in the disease course, given the fact that multiple rounds of treatment with systemic antibiotics are often required for a clinical effect.

Key learning point: Initial treatment of mild-to-moderate, predominantly comedonal acne vulgaris is a topical retinoid agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) have no role in the treatment of typical acne vulgaris. They are reserved for highly inflammatory nodulocystic disease (such as acne fulminans) and are used only for a limited duration, often while initiating systemic isotretinoin.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic antibiotics (e.g., oral doxycycline) may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris, but they should not be used as monotherapy for acne. Furthermore, systemic antibiotics are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin) may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris, but they should not be used as monotherapy. Furthermore, topical antibiotics are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole 2% cream is effective for treating seborrheic dermatitis, which is characterized by erythematous papules and greasy scale in a central facial distribution, often with involvement of the scalp and facial hair (eyebrows, eyelashes, beard). This patientâ€™s presentation is not consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with acne on her face and upper chest for the past 4 years. She is embarrassed by the involvement on her face. She has been using an over-the-counter face wash containing 5% benzoyl peroxide daily for the past month with improvement in the redness but not the bumps.
On examination, comedones are noted on her forehead (figure), nose, cheeks, and upper chest. There are no significant inflammatory lesions.
Which one of the following next steps is best for treating this patient's acne?

choices.text: Replace benzoyl peroxide with topical clindamycin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral minocycline is approved for the treatment of moderate-to-severe inflammatory acne vulgaris that is not predominantly nodular.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral isotretinoin is recommended for the treatment of severe nodulocystic acne and would not be indicated in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin) may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris, but they should not be used as monotherapy. Furthermore, topical antibiotics are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease because they have no keratolytic (pore unclogging) activity.

D) CORRECT:

Acne severity can be classified clinically as mild, moderate, or severe â€” and more precisely as comedonal (clogged pores), inflammatory (papules and pustules), nodulocystic, or a combination.

The patient in this vignette can be classified as having mild-to-moderate comedonal acne with mild inflammation that has improved with the use of benzoyl peroxide. She has no evidence of inflammatory papules or pustules or cystic or nodular lesions. Individuals with darker skin tones may present with hyperpigmented macules consistent with postinflammatory hyperpigmentation at sites of prior acneiform lesions.

Topical retinoids (such as adapalene, tretinoin, and tazarotene) are the best choice to treat comedonal and mild inflammatory acne; they can be used either as monotherapy or in topical combination products. Retinoids help normalize desquamation of the follicular epithelium and promote the clearing of existing microcomedones. In one study, 75% of patients with mild or moderate acne saw significant improvement with topical retinoids within 12 weeks.

Key learning point: Initial treatment of comedonal acne consists of benzoyl peroxide, topical retinoids, or topical combination agents.

E) INCORRECT:

Although salicylic acid is generally effective for treating acne as a mild comedolytic and antiinflammatory agent, it is less effective than treatment with topical retinoids.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl is evaluated for a rash on her forehead and nose that first appeared 6 months ago. She notes that the rash waxes and wanes, with bumps that are often white in appearance and are occasionally red and painful. She uses soap and water to wash her face and uses no other skin-care products.
On examination, she has a normal BMI and a sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) of 3 for breast development and 2 for pubic hair. There are scattered pinpoint pustules admixed with red papules primarily on her forehead, cheeks, and nose (figure). There is no scarring.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impetigo is caused by Staphylococcus aureus or group A streptococcus and often occurs at sites of breakage in the skin. It usually appears as pustules or blisters/vesicles that break open and ooze fluid, forming a yellow crust. It is most frequently observed in preschool-age children and young school-age children.

B) CORRECT:

Preadolescent acne is characterized by a predominance of comedones (clogged pores) on the forehead and central face (the T-zone) with relatively few inflammatory lesions. Open comedones appear as black dots (blackheads), and closed comedones appear as small noninflammatory pustules (whiteheads). Acne vulgaris is seen in up to 75% of girls aged 9 to 10.

In general, acne is uncomplicated by systemic disease, but it may be a cutaneous manifestation of underlying pathology. Workup is rarely needed and depends on the patient's age and physical findings. The physical examination should focus on the type and distribution of acne lesions, presence of hirsutism, growth parameters (BMI), and blood pressure in order to detect clinical signs of hormonal dysregulation, such as polycystic ovary syndrome or metabolic syndrome.

Key learning point: Preadolescent acne is characterized by a predominance of comedones on the forehead and central face (the T-zone), with relatively few inflammatory lesions.

C) INCORRECT:

Facial angiofibromas, previously known as adenoma sebaceum, are seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis complex and can be misdiagnosed as acne in adolescents. Facial angiofibromas often manifest in early childhood and persist throughout adulthood. Lesions are usually small, smooth papules on the bilateral cheeks and nose. This condition does not feature comedones, pustules, or cysts.

D) INCORRECT:

Verruca plana (flat warts) are caused by human papillomavirus and are a common viral infection of the skin. They can occur on the face, arms, and legs. Verruca plana are small, flat-topped papules that can manifest in clusters due to contiguous spread. Verruca plana do not feature comedones, pustules, or cysts.

E) INCORRECT:

Keratosis pilaris is characterized by keratinous plugs in the follicles and varying degrees of perifollicular erythema, most often on the upper outer extremities. Keratosis pilaris can occur on the cheeks as well, but its appearance as acuminate keratotic papules and its distribution on the lateral cheeks rather than the T-zone differentiate it from acne.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl who began menstruating at 12 years of age presents with acne on her face and upper chest. She is embarrassed by the involvement on her face. She has been using an over-the-counter face wash containing 5% benzoyl peroxide daily for the past month with improvement in the redness but not the bumps.
On examination, comedones are noted on her forehead (figure), nose, cheeks, and upper chest. There are no significant inflammatory lesions.
Which one of the following next steps is best for treating this patient's acne?

choices.text: Replace benzoyl peroxide with salicylic acid

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acne severity can be classified clinically as mild, moderate, or severe â€” and more precisely as comedonal (clogged pores), inflammatory (papules and pustules), nodulocystic, or a combination.

The patient in this vignette can be classified as having mild-to-moderate comedonal acne with mild inflammation that has improved with the use of benzoyl peroxide. She has no evidence of inflammatory papules or pustules or cystic or nodular lesions. Individuals with darker skin tones may present with hyperpigmented macules consistent with postinflammatory hyperpigmentation at sites of prior acneiform lesions.

Topical retinoids (such as adapalene, tretinoin, and tazarotene) are the best choice to treat comedonal and mild inflammatory acne; they can be used either as monotherapy or in topical combination products. Retinoids work by unplugging clogged pores, normalizing desquamation of the follicular epithelium, and promoting the clearing of existing microcomedones. In one study, 75% of patients with mild or moderate acne saw significant improvement with topical retinoids within 12 weeks.

Key learning point: Initial treatment of comedonal acne consists of benzoyl peroxide, topical retinoids, or topical combination agents.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin) may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris. However, they are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease because they have no keratolytic (pore unclogging) activity.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral isotretinoin is recommended for the treatment of severe nodulocystic acne.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral minocycline is approved for the treatment of moderate-to-severe inflammatory acne vulgaris that is not predominantly nodular.

E) INCORRECT:

Salicylic acid should not be used in place of benzoyl peroxide, which is a cornerstone of comedonal acne therapy and prevents bacterial resistance. Although salicylic acid is generally effective for treating acne as a mild comedolytic and antiinflammatory agent, it is less effective than treatment with topical retinoids.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents with progressively worsening skin lesions on his face. He has been treating the lesions with antibacterial soap and witch hazel astringent with no improvement. He uses no other cosmetics or medications on his face. He is healthy and takes no systemic medications.
On physical examination, he generally appears well. He has extensive open and closed comedones on the face (figure). There is dyspigmentation (consistent with postinflammatory hyperpigmentation) but no obvious scarring on the face.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic antibiotics (e.g., oral doxycycline) may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris, but they should not be used as monotherapy for acne. Furthermore, systemic antibiotics are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has moderate facial acne with a predominance of comedones. The extent of pigmentary changes at sites of prior acne lesions further supports the diagnosis of moderate acne. Topical retinoid preparations are the first-line therapy for comedonal acne. Topical retinoids (creams or gels) are also effective for treating mild-to-moderate inflammatory papulopustular acne vulgaris.

Recognizing the distinct morphologies in acne vulgaris guides selection of treatment. In a patient with predominantly comedonal acne, a topical retinoid, such as tretinoin 0.025% or adapalene 0.1% cream or gel, is an excellent first-line choice. Alternative (second-line) keratolytic agents include salicylic acid, glycolic acid, and azelaic acid. Topical azelaic acid may also help improve pigmentary changes. Cleansing with benzoyl peroxide may be helpful for patients with comedonal acne, because it is a mild keratolytic and has antibacterial properties that may help to prevent development of other types of acne such as pustules.

Topical or systemic antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin, doxycycline) should not be used as monotherapy and are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease. Adjunctive antibiotic therapy may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris, especially when it involves the back or chest, because consistently applying topical medications over these anatomic sites can be a challenge. Antibiotic therapy is not recommended for extended periods of time (more than 6 to 12 months) given the potential risk for developing antibiotic resistance. If acne does not respond to systemic antibiotic therapy after 3 to 6 months, treatment with isotretinoin is often considered. Isotretinoin is also frequently considered earlier in the disease course, given the fact that multiple rounds of treatment with systemic antibiotics are often required for a clinical effect.

Key learning point: Initial treatment of mild-to-moderate, predominantly comedonal acne vulgaris is a topical retinoid agent.

C) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole 2% cream is effective for treating seborrheic dermatitis, which is characterized by erythematous papules and greasy scale in a central facial distribution, often with involvement of the scalp and facial hair (eyebrows, eyelashes, beard). This patientâ€™s presentation is not consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) have no role in the treatment of typical acne vulgaris. They are reserved for highly inflammatory nodulocystic disease (such as acne fulminans) and are used only for a limited duration, often while initiating systemic isotretinoin.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin) may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris, but they should not be used as monotherapy. Furthermore, topical antibiotics are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has had severe acne on her face, chest, and back for the past 2 years. She has been treated in the past with oral azithromycin and a topical combination of benzoyl peroxide and adapalene without clinical improvement. She has no history of serious illness, and her menses have been regular. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. Examination shows mild facial scarring and numerous open comedones and sebaceous skin lesions on her face, chest, and back. Before initiating treatment with a new medication, which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Screen for depression with a questionnaire

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Before initiating oral retinoid therapy in women of childbearing age, an approved form of primary contraception (e.g., combined oral contraceptive pill) and a secondary barrier method must be initiated. Progestin-only oral contraceptives are not as effective as combined oral contraceptive pills and are not recommended for contraception in patients taking oral retinoids. Moreover, a different step is necessary before combined oral contraceptive pills are initiated.

Combined oral contraceptive pills have an antiandrogenic effect and can be used as an adjunct to treat severe inflammatory acne but progestin-only contraception can worsen acne.

B) INCORRECT:

Depression and suicidal ideation have been reported in patients taking retinoids, but current research does not support a causative link between this group of drugs and depression. A formal questionnaire-based screening test for depression is not routinely performed before initiating therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetracyclines such as doxycycline should be avoided in patients receiving systemic treatment with retinoids because both drugs increase the risk of pseudotumor cerebri. If adjunctive antibiotic therapy is indicated (e.g., because of inflammatory acne), amoxicillin or cephalexin are acceptable agents.

D) CORRECT:

Two separate serum or urine pregnancy tests should be performed in all female patients prior to systemic therapy with retinoids because this group of drugs is extremely teratogenic. If the initial pregnancy tests are negative, an approved form of primary contraception (e.g., IUD, combined oral contraceptive pill) and a secondary barrier method (e.g., condoms, cervical cap plus spermicide, diaphragm plus spermicide) must be used for a month before initiating oral retinoid therapy and continued up until one month after treatment is completed. Pregnancy tests should be repeated monthly while systemic retinoid therapy is ongoing and one month after ceasing therapy.

This patient should also undergo liver function and lipid profile tests (both before and during therapy) since the use of retinoids is associated with impaired liver function and hyperlipidemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum androgens (e.g., DHEA-S, total and free testosterone, androstenedione) in a female patient with acne vulgaris is only indicated if features of polycystic ovarian syndrome (e.g., ultrasonographic evidence of polycystic ovaries, menstrual irregularities), Cushing syndrome (e.g., truncal obesity), or hyperandrogenism (e.g., precocious puberty, hirsutism, clitoromegaly) are present.
questions.hint: This patient with severe acne vulgaris has failed to respond to initial therapy. As a next step, treatment with an oral retinoid (e.g., isotretinoin) should be initiated.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the office because of skin changes on his face, chest, and back over the past year. Treatment with over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide has been ineffective. Physical examination shows numerous open comedones, inflammatory papules, and pustules on his face, chest, and back. Which of the following is most likely to have contributed to the development of this patient's skin condition?

choices.text: Formation of superficial epidermal inclusion cysts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A type IV hypersensitivity reaction is the mechanism underlying allergic contact dermatitis, which occurs in susceptible individuals after repeat skin exposure to an allergen. Lesions in allergic contact dermatitis are intensely pruritic, erythematous, and papular, although they can also be vesicular in nature. The distribution and characterization of the lesions in this patient are not consistent with allergic contact dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperplasia of pilosebaceous glands occurs in rosacea with phymatous changes. Rosacea typically affects individuals 30â€“60 years old, and can cause disfiguring enlargement of the nose, known as rhinophyma. This patient has comedonal lesions, which are not expected in rosacea, and he does not have rhinophyma or other symptoms of rosacea.

C) INCORRECT:

Dysfunction of apocrine glands is believed to contribute to hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), an inflammatory skin disorder affecting areas with abundant apocrine sweat glands including the axilla, groin, and perineum. Lesions in HS can form abscesses, fistulas, and draining sinuses with foul odor. This patient exhibits none of these clinical features.

D) CORRECT:

Increased levels of androgen, as present during puberty, stimulate sebum production, which can lead to the obstruction of pilosebaceous units within the epidermis. This obstruction results in clogged pores, or comedones, which are characteristic of acne vulgaris. In response to excessive sebum secretion, Cutibacterium acnes can proliferate within the pilosebaceous unit and induce an inflammatory reaction with the formation of papules, nodules, pustules, and/or cysts.
Image Description:

Disseminated papules, pustules, and comedones on an erythematous base are visible on the seborrheic skin of the patient's forehead.

These findings are consistent with moderate acne vulgaris.

E) INCORRECT:

Formation of superficial epidermal inclusion cysts is the underlying mechanism of milia. Milia is a benign skin disorder typically affecting neonates, marked by small white papules on the nose and cheeks that resolve spontaneously. The inflammatory, comedonal nature of this patient's skin lesions and distribution on the face, back, and chest are inconsistent with milia.
questions.hint: Open comedones and inflammatory papules and pustules in an adolescent patient are characteristic of acne vulgaris, an extremely common disorder of pilosebaceous follicles.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman with a 15-year history of acne expresses frustration with her current therapy (benzoyl peroxide and tretinoin cream), because she continues to get inflammatory papules and pustules and occasional deep-seated cystic lesions on her face, chest, and back. She does not have extensive scarring and is not pregnant or planning pregnancy. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics (including clindamycin) are used to treat mild-to-moderate inflammatory acne. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has predominantly inflammatory acne that has failed to respond to appropriate topical therapy. There are several potential treatment options for her, including addition of an oral antibiotic, hormonal therapy such as oral contraceptive pills, and isotretinoin.

Tetracyclines (tetracycline, doxycycline, and minocycline) are among the most commonly used oral antibiotics for acne and are considered to be the most effective antibiotics for this purpose.

Ideally, this patient will continue the benzoyl peroxide and retinoid (in addition to starting the oral antibiotic), to control coincident comedonal disease and in anticipation of tapering or discontinuing the oral therapy. If no improvement is noted after 3 months of oral therapy, the oral antibiotic may be changed, hormonal therapy may be instituted, and/or isotretinoin can be considered. Isotretinoin is indicated when patients have severe nodulocystic acne or scarring that has not responded to oral antibiotics. Since prolonged treatment with oral antibiotics is not recommended because of the potential for bacterial resistance, more providers are opting for hormonal therapies and/or isotretinoin upon failure of one systemic antibiotic.

Key learning point: Inflammatory acne that has not responded to appropriate topical therapy is best treated with an oral antibiotic, such as doxycycline.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical retinoids (including tretinoin and tazarotene) are used to treat comedonal acne, while topical antibiotics (including clindamycin) are used to treat mild-to-moderate inflammatory acne. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

D) INCORRECT:

Combination topical agents such as clindamycin-benzoyl peroxide are convenient for the patient and increase efficacy by increasing compliance, but they do not offer additional efficacy for severe inflammatory and cystic disease. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical retinoids like adapalene are used to treat comedonal acne. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with progressively worsening skin lesions on his face. He has been treating the lesions with antibacterial soap and witch hazel astringent with no improvement. On physical examination, he generally appears well. He has extensive open and closed comedones on the face (figure). There is dyspigmentation (consistent with postinflammatory hyperpigmentation) but no obvious scarring on the face. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical or systemic antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline) may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris, but they are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease. Systemic antibiotics are indicated for moderate-to-severe papulopustular acne vulgaris, especially when it involves the back or chest, because consistently applying topical medications over these anatomic sites can be a challenge. Antibiotic monotherapy is not recommended for extended periods of time (more than 6 to 12 months) given the potential risk for developing antibiotic resistance. If acne does not respond after 3 to 6 months, treatment with isotretinoin is now often considered.

B) CORRECT:

In a patient with predominantly comedonal acne, a topical retinoid, such as tretinoin or adapalene, is an excellent first-line choice. Topical retinoid preparations are the first-line therapy for comedonal acne. Recognizing the distinct morphologies in acne vulgaris guides selection of treatment. Cleansing with benzoyl peroxide may be helpful for patients with comedonal acne, because it is a mild keratolytic and has antibacterial properties that may help to prevent development of other types of acne such as pustules.

Key learning point: Initial treatment of mild-to-moderate, predominantly comedonal acne vulgaris is a topical retinoid agent.

C) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole cream is effective for treating seborrheic dermatitis, which is characterized by erythematous papules and greasy scale in a central facial distribution, often with involvement of the scalp and facial hair (eyebrows, eyelashes, beard). This patientâ€™s presentation is not consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) have no role in the treatment of typical acne vulgaris. They are reserved for highly inflammatory nodulocystic disease (such as acne fulminans) and are used only for a limited duration, often while initiating systemic isotretinoin.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical or systemic antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin) may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris, but they are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease. Systemic antibiotics are indicated for moderate-to-severe papulopustular acne vulgaris, especially when it involves the back or chest, because consistently applying topical medications over these anatomic sites can be a challenge. Antibiotic monotherapy is not recommended for extended periods of time (more than 6 to 12 months) given the potential risk for developing antibiotic resistance. If acne does not respond after 3 to 6 months, treatment with isotretinoin is now often considered.
questions.hint: This patient's facial acne with a predominance of comedones and pigmentary changes at sites of prior acne lesions is indicative of mild-moderate acne.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 18-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-year history of severe acne vulgaris over her face, upper back, and arms. Treatment with oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy with benzoyl peroxide and retinoid has not completely resolved her symptoms. Examination shows oily skin with numerous comedones, pustules, and scarring over the face and upper back. Long-term therapy is started with combined oral contraceptives. This patient's new medication significantly reduces the risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-term COC use (â‰¥ 5 years) is associated with an increased risk of developing cervical cancer. The mechanism by which they do this is unclear, but it is hypothesized that these medications increase the susceptibility of cervical cells to human papillomavirus infection (the main cause of cervical cancer) and/or decrease the ability of cervical cells to clear this infection.

B) CORRECT:

For female patients with continued severe acne vulgaris despite first-line therapies (e.g., oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy), COCs can be added. Besides having positive effects on acne vulgaris, the progestin contained in COCs opposes estrogen-driven endometrial hyperplasia, which reduces the risk of developing type 1 endometrial cancer. This risk decreases with a longer duration of COC use, and protection persists for many years after drug cessation. COCs also reduce the risk of developing ovarian cancer, possibly through reduced cell proliferation within the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

C) INCORRECT:

COC therapy is associated with an increased risk of developing deep vein thrombosis since estrogen induces transcription of clotting factors (II, VII, VIII, X, XII) and fibrinogen to promote clot formation.

D) INCORRECT:

COC therapy increases the risk of developing hypertension, although this risk minimizes shortly after drug cessation. The mechanism of oral contraception-induced hypertension is unclear but may be related to increased serum angiotensinogen concentrations.

E) INCORRECT:

COC therapy does not reduce the risk of developing breast cancer. However, there is controversy as to whether these medications actually increase the risk of developing breast cancer and, therefore, should be used with caution in patients with high risk for breast cancer development (e.g., due to BRCA mutations).
questions.hint: Progestin, a component of combined oral contraceptives (COCs), opposes the effects of estrogen.

questions.text: A 3-week-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for a well-child examination. She has been well, but her mother is concerned about a rash that appeared on her cheeks 6 days ago. She has not had any other symptoms. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery and is exclusively breastfed. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 75th percentile for length and weight and at the 60th percentile for head circumference. A photograph of the patient's rash is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding this newborn's rash?

choices.text: Breathable fabrics and avoidance of heat
Daily cleansing with water and soap

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Breathable fabrics and avoidance of heat are measures used to avoid and treat miliaria rubra. Although miliaria rubra also manifests with an erythematous, papulopustular rash, it more commonly develops in areas that are prone to sweating and occlusion (e.g., intertriginous skin folds of the neck, axilla, and groin). Breathable fabrics and avoidance of heat are unlikely to improve neonatal cephalic pustulosis.
Image Description:

Multiple, partially confluent papules on erythematous skin are visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical mupirocin is used to treat impetigo, which can manifest with erythematous papules and pustules. However, these lesions typically rupture and leave shallow erosions covered in honey-colored crust. Moreover, children between the ages of 2 and 4 are most commonly affected. Topical mupirocin is not used to treat neonatal cephalic pustulosis.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical tacrolimus is used to treat atopic dermatitis, often in conjunction with topical corticosteroids. Atopic dermatitis can manifest in infancy with an erythematous rash on the face but more commonly results in scaly, eczematous plaques without pustules. In addition, these lesions are often intensely pruritic and cause discomfort and irritability. Topical tacrolimus is not used to treat neonatal cephalic pustulosis.
Image Description:

Erythematous and scaly papules coalescing into plaques can be seen on the face of this infant.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral isotretinoin can be used to treat severe infantile acne. Although this condition usually manifests with erythematous papules and pustules, the presentation is usually much more severe than that of neonatal cephalic pustulosis and also includes comedones (and sometimes nodules). Moreover, infantile acne most commonly manifests around 3 months of age. Oral isotretinoin is not used to treat neonatal cephalic pustulosis.

E) CORRECT:

Neonatal cephalic pustulosis is a benign, self-limited condition that typically resolves within a few months and does not leave scars. Management includes daily cleansing with water and soap and avoidance of oils and lotions, which can occlude the skin and exacerbate this condition. More severe cases can be treated with topical antifungals (e.g., ketoconazole cream) and mild topical corticosteroids (e.g., hydrocortisone cream).
questions.hint: This patient has neonatal cephalic pustulosis, which most commonly manifests in the first few weeks of life on the face and/or scalp with an erythematous, papulopustular rash without comedones.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with acne on her face and upper chest. She is embarrassed by the involvement on her face. She has been using an over-the-counter face wash containing benzoyl peroxide daily for the past month with improvement in the redness but not the bumps. On examination, comedones are noted on her forehead, nose, cheeks, and upper chest. There are no significant inflammatory lesions. Which one of the following next steps is best for treating this patient's acne?

choices.text: Replace benzoyl peroxide with salicylic acid

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Topical retinoids (such as adapalene, tretinoin, and tazarotene) are the best choice to treat comedonal and mild inflammatory acne; they can be used either as monotherapy or in topical combination products. Retinoids work by unplugging clogged pores, normalizing desquamation of the follicular epithelium, and promoting the clearing of existing microcomedones. In one study, 75% of patients with mild or moderate acne saw significant improvement with topical retinoids within 12 weeks.

Key learning point: Initial treatment of comedonal acne consists of benzoyl peroxide, topical retinoids, or topical combination agents.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotic monotherapy, such as clindamycin, is not recommended for comedones because it has no keratolytic (pore unclogging) activity. It is used for mild inflammatory acne (papules, pustules).

C) INCORRECT:

Oral isotretinoin is recommended for the treatment of severe nodulocystic acne.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral minocycline is approved for the treatment of moderate-to-severe inflammatory acne vulgaris that is not predominantly nodular.

E) INCORRECT:

Salicylic acid should not be used in place of benzoyl peroxide, which is a cornerstone of comedonal acne therapy and prevents bacterial resistance. Although salicylic acid is generally effective for treating acne as a mild comedolytic and antiinflammatory agent, it is less effective than treatment with topical retinoids.
questions.hint: Acne severity can be classified clinically as mild, moderate, or severe â€” and more precisely as comedonal (clogged pores), inflammatory (papules and pustules), nodulocystic, or a combination. The patient in this vignette can be classified as having mild-to-moderate comedonal acne with mild inflammation that has improved with the use of benzoyl peroxide.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to your clinic with a 3-year history of acne on her face and chest. She reports no itching or scaling. She is concerned about possible facial scarring and has not previously sought treatment. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 160 cm tall and weighs 58 kg; BMI is 23. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are several open comedones on her face and chest. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Monotherapy with topical benzoyl peroxide is a first-line treatment option for mild noninflammatory acne vulgaris. Benzoyl peroxide has a comedolytic as well as a bactericidal effect, which can reduce Cutibacterium acnes colonization. Benzoyl peroxide also prevents bacterial resistance and should be added to topical or systemic antibiotic regimens. Other first-line treatment options for mild acne vulgaris include topical retinoid monotherapy, benzoyl peroxide + topical antibiotics, benzoyl peroxide + topical retinoid, and benzoyl peroxide + topical antibiotic + topical retinoid. The choice of medication depends on the severity of acne vulgaris, provider preference, and prior treatment.

Key learning point: Topical benzoyl peroxide is a first-line treatment for mild noninflammatory acne vulgaris due to its comedolytic and antibacterial properties.
Image Description:

The skin of the patient shows multiple papules and pustules on an erythematous base. In addition, several open comedones with the characteristic darkening (blackheads) are visible.

These findings are characteristic of acne vulgaris.

B) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives can be prescribed as an adjunct therapy for female patients who do not respond to first-line therapy of acne vulgaris. Since this patient has not yet trialed any first-line treatments, combined oral contraceptives are not indicated at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral isotretinoin is reserved for the treatment of severe acne vulgaris (e.g., nodular acne) and moderate inflammatory acne that causes scarring because of its severe side effect profile (e.g., hepatic toxicity, birth defects). This patient has mild acne vulgaris and has not yet received a first-line treatment. Therefore, oral isotretinoin would not be appropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with topical antibiotics is not recommended for acne vulgaris treatment because of the potential development of antibiotic resistance. Instead, topical or systemic antibiotics should be used in conjunction with another specific agent in which there has been no reported resistance.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics can be used for the treatment of moderate to severe acne vulgaris, but they should be used in combination with another agent to prevent bacterial resistance and for an additional comedolytic or keratin-reducing effect. This patient has mild noninflammatory acne vulgaris, which means that oral antibiotics would not be the first-line treatment.
questions.hint: Open comedones (also known as blackheads) on the face and chest are characteristic of mild noninflammatory acne vulgaris.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to your clinic with a one-year history of skin changes on his face, chest, and back. He has tried over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide without improvement. On examination, there are numerous open comedones, inflammatory papules, and pustules on his face, chest, and back. Which one of the following is most likely to have contributed to the development of his skin condition?

choices.text: Formation of superficial epidermal inclusion cysts.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperplasia of pilosebaceous glands occurs in rosacea with phymatous changes. Rosacea typically affects individuals 30â€“60 years old, and can cause disfiguring enlargement of the nose, known as rhinophyma. This patient has comedonal lesions, which are not expected in rosacea, and he does not have rhinophyma or other symptoms of rosacea.

B) INCORRECT:

Dysfunction of apocrine glands is believed to contribute to hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), an inflammatory skin disorder affecting areas with abundant apocrine sweat glands including the axilla, groin, and perineum. Lesions in HS can form abscesses, fistulas, and draining sinuses with foul odor. This patient exhibits none of these clinical features.

C) INCORRECT:

Formation of superficial epidermal inclusion cysts is the underlying mechanism of milia. Milia is a benign skin disorder typically affecting neonates, marked by small white papules on the nose and cheeks that resolve spontaneously. The inflammatory, comedonal nature of this patient's skin lesions and distribution on the face, back, and chest are inconsistent with milia.

D) INCORRECT:

A type IV hypersensitivity reaction is the mechanism underlying allergic contact dermatitis, which occurs in susceptible individuals after repeat skin exposure to an allergen. Lesions in allergic contact dermatitis are intensely pruritic, erythematous, and papular, although they can also be vesicular in nature. The distribution and characterization of the lesions in this patient are not consistent with allergic contact dermatitis.

E) CORRECT:

Increased levels of androgen, as present during puberty, stimulate sebum production, which can lead to the obstruction of pilosebaceous units within the epidermis. This obstruction results in clogged pores, or comedones, which are characteristic of acne vulgaris. In response to excessive sebum secretion, Cutibacterium acnes can proliferate within the pilosebaceous unit and induce an inflammatory reaction with the formation of papules, nodules, pustules, and/or cysts.

Key learning point: Increased androgen levels during puberty stimulate sebum production, leading to clogged pilosebaceous units and the development of acne vulgaris.
Image Description:

Disseminated papules, pustules, and comedones on an erythematous base are visible on the seborrheic skin of the patient's forehead.

These findings are consistent with moderate acne vulgaris.
questions.hint: Open comedones and inflammatory papules and pustules in an adolescent patient are characteristic of acne vulgaris, an extremely common disorder of pilosebaceous follicles.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 15-year history of acne. She is frustrated with her current treatment regimen of benzoyl peroxide and tretinoin cream, as she continues to experience inflammatory papules, pustules, and occasional deep-seated cystic lesions on her face, chest, and back. She does not have extensive scarring and is not pregnant or planning pregnancy. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for her?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics (including clindamycin) are used to treat mild-to-moderate inflammatory acne. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has predominantly inflammatory acne that has failed to respond to appropriate topical therapy. There are several potential treatment options for her, including addition of an oral antibiotic, hormonal therapy such as oral contraceptive pills, and isotretinoin.

Tetracyclines (tetracycline, doxycycline, and minocycline) are among the most commonly used oral antibiotics for acne and are considered to be the most effective antibiotics for this purpose.

Ideally, this patient will continue the benzoyl peroxide and retinoid (in addition to starting the oral antibiotic), to control coincident comedonal disease and in anticipation of tapering or discontinuing the oral therapy. If no improvement is noted after 3 months of oral therapy, the oral antibiotic may be changed, hormonal therapy may be instituted, and/or isotretinoin can be considered. Isotretinoin is indicated when patients have severe nodulocystic acne or scarring that has not responded to oral antibiotics. Since prolonged treatment with oral antibiotics is not recommended because of the potential for bacterial resistance, more providers are opting for hormonal therapies and/or isotretinoin upon failure of one systemic antibiotic.

Key learning point: Inflammatory acne that has not responded to appropriate topical therapy is best treated with an oral antibiotic, such as doxycycline.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical retinoids (including tretinoin and tazarotene) are used to treat comedonal acne, while topical antibiotics (including clindamycin) are used to treat mild-to-moderate inflammatory acne. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

D) INCORRECT:

Combination topical agents such as clindamycin-benzoyl peroxide are convenient for the patient and increase efficacy by increasing compliance, but they do not offer additional efficacy for severe inflammatory and cystic disease. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical retinoids like adapalene are used to treat comedonal acne. This patient's acne has not responded to topical treatment and now requires systemic therapy rather than more or stronger topical treatments.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to your clinic with progressively worsening skin lesions on his face. He has been using antibacterial soap and witch hazel astringent without improvement. On examination, he has extensive open and closed comedones on his face (see figure). There is dyspigmentation consistent with postinflammatory hyperpigmentation, but no scarring is present. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) have no role in the treatment of typical acne vulgaris. They are reserved for highly inflammatory nodulocystic disease (such as acne fulminans) and are used only for a limited duration, often while initiating systemic isotretinoin.

B) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole cream is effective for treating seborrheic dermatitis, which is characterized by erythematous papules and greasy scale in a central facial distribution, often with involvement of the scalp and facial hair (eyebrows, eyelashes, beard). This patientâ€™s presentation is not consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with predominantly comedonal acne, a topical retinoid, such as tretinoin or adapalene, is an excellent first-line choice. Topical retinoid preparations are the first-line therapy for comedonal acne. Recognizing the distinct morphologies in acne vulgaris guides selection of treatment. Cleansing with benzoyl peroxide may be helpful for patients with comedonal acne, because it is a mild keratolytic and has antibacterial properties that may help to prevent development of other types of acne such as pustules.

Key learning point: Initial treatment of mild-to-moderate, predominantly comedonal acne vulgaris is a topical retinoid agent.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical or systemic antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin) may benefit patients with inflammatory papular or pustular acne vulgaris, but they are unlikely to benefit patients with largely comedonal disease.
